summary: For years, private equity’s record on diversity has been the subject of criticism from outside the industry and hand-wringing inside, but without, on the whole, much change in the overall gender or racial breakdown. Could things finally be improving? A recent report that Yale University’s David Swenson is threatening to cut loose asset managers that don’t hit diversity targets could be the start of a shift. That could be a challenge for private-equity firms, many of which have grown used to treating diversity on their investment staffs as something they would like to have, but don’t need to have.

title: The Florida Bank that Embraced the Main Street Lending Program; ECB’s Lane Hints at Inflation Overshoot; BOE Asks Banks About Readiness for Negative Rates
summary: Most banks have steered clear of the Fed’s loan program designed to buoy midsize businesses, but Miami-based City National Bank of Florida is diving in. A top European Central Bank official told the Journal the bank would be just as aggressive as the Fed in stimulating the region’s economy as it recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic, implying the ECB would also allow inflation to overshoot its target. Meanwhile, the Bank of England asked British lenders to assess their readiness for subzero interest rates, the latest sign that officials are weighing the merits of such a policy.

title: Gabon Fixes Cocoa Prices for 2020-2021 Season
How Investors Are Trading November’s Election
summary: With market volatility rising ahead of U.S. presidential and congressional elections, investors are parsing what polls and policy proposals mean for everything from energy stocks to shares of private-prison operators.

title: Bolivia Flirts With the Return of Evo
summary: Will a divided opposition give the election to pro-Cuba, cocaine traffickers?

title: Renewable-Energy Stocks Are Getting a Biden Bump
summary: Three funds, which investors are betting stand to benefit from Joe Biden’s green-energy proposals, are up more than 80% this year.

title: Bayer, BASF Fight to Keep Weedkiller on U.S. Farms
summary: The chemicals makers are hoping the EPA responds to a court-ordered ban on their dicamba herbicides by allowing them back on the market despite complaints about crop damage.

title: Libya Restarts Oil Production at Biggest Field
summary: The move could quickly increase Libya’s overall output after an extended shutdown and add to a glut of oil on world markets that has kept prices low.

title: Emerging and Growth Markets, October 10th 2020
summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting emerging and growth markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

title: Yemen Peace Process Falters as Fighting Intensifies and Hunger Spreads
summary: New fronts have opened in the six-year conflict, threatening to unspool a stalled peace process and deepen what aid groups call the world’s worst humanitarian catastrophe.

title: Transcript: WSJ Interview With ECB’s Philip R. Lane
summary: Philip R. Lane, a member of the European Central Bank’s executive board, discusses the economic outlook, the potential for more ECB stimulus, negative interest rates and the euro exchange rate.

title: Top Official Signals ECB Would Allow Inflation to Overshoot
summary: The ECB’s chief economist says the eurozone economy faces a rocky patch after an initial rebound from its sharp spring contraction, with inflation still far too weak.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Kamala Harris and Mike Pence clashed at the vice-presidential debate, six were charged with plotting to kidnap Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, Kyrgyzstan’s president declared a state of emergency and more from The Wall Street Journal’s photo editors.
